description.narrative: The IDH Tropical Timber program promotes the use of sustainable tropical timber. For IDH it is evident that sustainable forest management ensures the forest is there for the future. IDH’s objective for the 2016-2020 period is to support certification of 2 million hectares of tropical forest – with FSC, PEFC or other credible standards – spread over strategic locations around the world. These locations will in some cases overlap with landscapes in which IDH works on preventing deforestation. In these landscapes, the timber program also aims to work on broader issues to support sustainable forest management and prevent deforestation, for example by working with national timber federations, large companies using local timber or alternative livelihood strategies. On the demand side, activities of the by IDH founded European Sustainable Tropical Timber Coalition will be scaled up to include sector wide action plans with timber trade federations, individual companies and municipalities in five focus countries: Germany, Denmark, France, Italy and Spain. Awareness of the fact that using sustainable tropical timber is good, to keep the forest is key. Since 2008, IDH has invested in promoting sustainable forest management, by supporting producers and mobilizing markets. It started with certification programs in the Amazon (Amazon Alternative program) and Indonesia (Borneo Initiative), and later the Congo Basin region, making the IDH Tropical Timber program the biggest forest certification program worldwide. By early 2016, over 8 million hectares of tropical forests in the three regions have been certified with the support of IDH, amounting to 50% of all current FSC certifications of forests in the tropics.

target.value: Sourcing sustainable timber at the following main companies involved in the program: the five Timber Trade Federations (Denmark, Germany, France, Spain and Italy) and their private sector partners.

actual.value: STTC supported the national timber trade federations of Denmark, Germany, France and Spain, which developed, improved and implemented their policy plans on sustainable tropical timber under the STTC. The STTC did not continue with the Italian Federation due to lack of willingness to participate. Selected actions include: • Germany was very active at the largest trade fairs in Germany, and developed a very simple, informative and attractive YouTube video on why sustainable tropical timber is important. This generated a good deal of attention and awareness, as tropical timber is still perceived as a commodity one shouldn’t use. The campaign very clearly explained why buying sustainable tropical timber saves forests. • France developed a digital toolkit with information relevant to each tropical timber importer and user. • The Danish Federation added a page dedicated to tropical timber to their website, linking to as many information sources as possible, also cooperating with ATIBT on Lesser Known Timber Species research work. This was an initiative supported by a coalition of ten Danish companies, demonstrating the willingness of the sector in Denmark to move forward. Individual company action plans were also implemented in 2017, such as that of Leroy Merlin (Spain), Lathams (UK) and Biomanderas (Germany). While the budgets for these action plans are small, the enthusiasm and learnings on a company level are high, as well as the outreach potential that these companies have. With the current increasing demand for tropical timber, these activities are especially important.

Through IDH support, the company WALE is working on marketing one specific lesser known timber species from Gabon, called Gombe. Lesser known timber species (LKTS) is important, as exploring other species of timber adds value to sustainably managed concessions, therefore improving the business case.
